content: The Act titled "Common Sense Spending Act of 2004" extends discretionary spending limits. The "Common Sense Spending Act of 2004" extends discretionary spending limits by specifying new budget authority and outlays for fiscal year 2005, including allocations for defense and homeland security activities. The "Common Sense Spending Act of 2004" sets new budget authority and outlays for fiscal years 2006, 2007, and 2008, with specific allocations for defense and homeland security categories. The "Common Sense Spending Act of 2004" establishes new budget authority for fiscal years 2008 and 2009, with adjustments based on the Consumer Price Index. Adjustments to discretionary spending limits are also outlined in the Act. Amendments to the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 involve changes to mandatory budget authority and outlays related to accrued Federal retirement and health benefits. The Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 is amended by removing the last sentence. The definition of Consumer Price Index is clarified as the Consumer Price Index for All Urban Consumers (all items; United States city average) published by the Bureau of Labor Statistics. SEC. 3. Extension of pay-as-you-go under the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 is amended to enforce pay-as-you-go. The purpose of this section is to ensure that any legislation enacted before October 1, 2009, increasing the deficit triggers an offsetting sequestration within 15 days of Congress adjourning. The Office of Management and Budget (OMB) will calculate the deficit increase or decrease by adding all estimates for the budget year of direct spending legislation. The legislation requires the calculation of savings in direct spending programs resulting from prior year's sequestration and any net deficit increase or decrease in the current year from OMB estimates for direct spending legislation. The legislation mandates OMB to assume a $7.4 billion deficit increase and outlines the process for sequestering funds from non-exempt direct spending accounts in a specific order. Each remaining non-exempt direct spending account shall be reduced by a uniform percentage necessary to achieve the required reduction in direct spending, with exceptions for certain programs like Medicare. Outlay reductions resulting from sequestration of Commodity Credit Corporation commodity price support contracts in the fiscal year of a sequestration will be credited for the following fiscal year. Accounts are assumed to be at the baseline level for fiscal year 2005 and adjusted for any sequester in fiscal years 2006 through 2009. CBO and OMB are required to provide estimates for direct spending legislation within specific timeframes. The OMB is required to provide estimates for direct spending legislation, including current economic assumptions and explanations for any differences between OMB and CBO estimates. If significant differences are found, OMB must consult with the Committees on the Budget of the House of Representatives and the Senate before issuing the report. The OMB and CBO must determine common scorekeeping guidelines and prepare estimates for direct spending legislation, excluding amounts from full funding of the deposit insurance guarantee commitment and emergency provisions. If emergency legislation is enacted, the President can designate it as such. Legislation designated as an emergency requirement by the President and Congress will have new budget authority, outlays, and receipts treated as emergency requirements in reports. SEC. 4. CONFORMING AMENDMENTS. Amends the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 to change the expiration date from "2002" to "2009" in various sections. SEC. 5 amends the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 regarding emergency spending legislation and the baseline. Emergency appropriations and legislation are specified not to be extended in the baseline. SEC. 6 addresses OMB emergency criteria. The definition of "emergency" under the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974 is a situation that requires new budget authority and outlays for the prevention, mitigation, or response to loss of life, property, or national security threat, and is unanticipated. "Unanticipated" means the situation is sudden and quickly arises. The term "emergency" is defined as a situation requiring immediate action, not predicted or of permanent duration, under the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974. This definition is also added to the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985. SEC. 7. RULE RESPECTING DESIGNATION OF LEGISLATIVE PROVISION AS AN EMERGENCY. This section amends the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 by adding a new rule regarding the designation of legislative provisions as emergencies. In designating legislation as an emergency requirement, the committee report must analyze if it meets the definition of an 'emergency' as outlined in the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974. Bills with emergency designations under the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 must also meet this definition to be considered in the Senate or House of Representatives. The Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974 outlines procedures for waiver and appeal in the Senate, requiring a three-fifths vote to suspend certain sections. In the House of Representatives, it is not allowed to consider a rule that waives subsection (b). The Chair in the House must put the question of consideration for a point of order, which is debatable for 10 minutes. The House of Representatives allows for 10 minutes of debate on a point of order, with an additional 10 minutes for an opponent. The question of consideration for a bill or joint resolution also applies to determining consideration for an amendment made in order as original text.
